awd_titl_txt: Redefining STEM Teacher Preparation by Teaching, Learning ,and Leading with Schools and Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the NSF Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, the Loyola University of Chicago (LUC) School of Education, College of Arts & Sciences, Center for Science and Math Education will partner with Chicago Public Schools (CPS) to recruit and prepare mathematics and science majors for careers in teaching secondary mathematics or science. Specifically, this project will recruit two to four undergraduate and up to three graduate LUC-Noyce Scholars per year, with each Scholar receiving one to two years of support, for a total of at least 24 new teachers prepared. The project will leverage and expand substantial existing school, community, and informal education partnerships in order to prepare teachers to support students' learning, development, and achievement within the complex realities of urban schools and communities. Further, by studying the implemented teacher preparation model, the project will advance knowledge about preparing STEM teachers in close collaboration with urban schools and communities.

The LUC-Noyce Scholars will be prepared through a program built on four key research-based cornerstones: (1) mutually-beneficial partnerships with schools and communities, (2) teacher preparation for diverse classrooms, (3) authentic teaching practices, and (4) participation in professional learning communities. The project will embed teacher education in Chicago schools and communities from the start to provide candidates with extensive opportunities to work alongside experts in high-need, high-performing educational settings, with an emphasis on fostering reflective teaching, learning and leadership skills. As part of the preparation to work with culturally and linguistically diverse students, all LUC-Noyce scholars will fulfill requirements for the Illinois State Board of Education's English as a second language (ESL) endorsement as well as the International Baccalaureate (IB) certification. LUC is the first undergraduate institution in the U.S. approved to prepare pre-service teachers in all three IB programmes: the Primary Years Programme (Grades K-5), the Middle Years Programme (Grades 5-10), and the Diploma Programme (Grades 11-12). Thus, this project will fill an important need to develop mathematics and science teachers who have the background, experience, and certification necessary to fill positions in the CPS high schools where all ninth and tenth grade students are enrolled in IB programs.

por.por_cntn:
Goals & Outcomes 

The LUC-Noyce Scholars project, a collaboration between the Loyola University Chicago (LUC) School of Education, College of Arts & Sciences, and Center for Science & Math Education, aimed to: a) increase the number of science and math majors (baccalaureate and post-baccalaureate) pursuing a teaching license and degree in secondary education; b) increase the diversity of science and math candidates in the university’s teacher education programs and thus the STEM teaching field overall; c) provide extensive experiences and resources for working with culturally and linguistically diverse students and be eligible for the state English as a second language (ESL) endorsement; d) retain LUC-Noyce Scholars in high-need schools following graduation through rigorous preparation combined with access to high quality resources and multi-dimensional supports; and e) conduct research to inform understandings about urban STEM teacher preparation, mentoring and induction support. 

Under these goals, the project provided 31 scholarship and stipend awards, thereby reducing financial barriers to enrolling in a teacher education program, particularly for candidates from backgrounds that are historically underrepresented in STEM fields. The project’s recruitment efforts also attracted STEM majors who had not previously considered teaching. The project succeeded in increasing the diversity of candidates in the LUC science and math teacher education programs by attracting women in STEM majors and from STEM-related industries, students from varied background/life experiences and income levels, and students from across all STEM majors where pathways to certification are offered (mathematics, biology, chemistry, physics, environmental science). The program has had excellent completion and retention rates. Out of the 31 awards, 29 program graduates are currently teaching or have already successfully completed at least two years teaching in a high need district. Decisions by the two who dropped out were influenced by hardships related to the COVID-19 pandemic. Additionally, 100% of LUC-Noyce Scholars fulfilled requirements for the Illinois English as a second language (ESL) endorsement, an expressed need of local schools. Progress on these and other related goals continues to be pursued under NSF 2243339. 

Broader Impacts 

Broader impacts of the project include the 29 credentialed teachers prepared to teach in high-need school districts, the majority of whom have remained teaching in high-need districts beyond their service obligation. Each of these teachers has influenced hundreds of high school students. 

Additionally, the project contributed to improved STEM educator development by creating a mentoring and induction program to provide a source of community for LUC-Noyce scholars during the COVID-19 pandemic. This mentoring and induction program has 

continued to grow and has proven to be a valuable support, involving 19 teachers from the start of their teacher education program through their first years of teaching. 

The project also advanced knowledge and disseminated findings that contribute to understandings about STEM teacher education and development. Relevant products include 3 peer-reviewed publications in leading science and science teacher education journals as well as over a dozen conference presentations by faculty, undergraduate and graduate scholars, and program alumni. Locally, project findings have influenced programmatic changes in LUC’s School of Education, including reorganization of student teaching supervision processes, expansion of community partnerships. Finally, new collaborations with the Biology Department and School of Environmental Sustainably have emerged including pre-service teacher research experiences in biodiversity studies (NSF 2151086).
